segments.en: Long Discourses 21
Sakka’s Questions
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati, pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṃ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans; east of Rājagaha there’s a brahmin village named Ambasaṇḍā, north of which, on Mount Vediyaka, is the Indasāla cave.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sakkassa devānamindassa ussukkaṃ udapādi bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
segments.en: Now at that time a keen desire to seeing the Buddha came over Sakka, the lord of gods.
He thought,

segments.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti?
segments.en: “Where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

segments.pli: Addasā kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ magadhesu viharantaṃ pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṃ.
segments.en: He saw that the Buddha was at the Indasāla cave,
and addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three,

segments.pli: “ayaṃ, mārisā, bhagavā magadhesu viharati, pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṃ.
segments.en: “Good sirs, the Buddha is staying in the land of the Magadhans at the Indasāla cave.

segments.pli: Yadi pana, mārisā, mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
segments.en: What if we were to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhaddantavā”ti kho devā tāvatiṃsā sakkassa devānamindassa paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, lord,” replied the gods.

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṃ gandhabbadevaputtaṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Sakka addressed the fairy Pañcasikha,

segments.pli: “ayaṃ, tāta pañcasikha, bhagavā magadhesu viharati pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṃ.
segments.en: “Dear Pañcasikha, the Buddha is staying in the land of the Magadhans at the Indasāla cave.

segments.pli: Yadi pana, tāta pañcasikha, mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
segments.en: What if we were to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ ādāya sakkassa devānamindassa anucariyaṃ upāgami.
segments.en: “Yes, lord,” replied the fairy Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went as Sakka’s attendant.

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo devehi tāvatiṃsehi parivuto pañcasikhena gandhabbadevaputtena purakkhato—
segments.en: Then Sakka went at the head of a retinue consisting of the gods of the Thirty-Three and the fairy Pañcasikha.

segments.pli: seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—devesu tāvatiṃsesu antarahito magadhesu pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate paccuṭṭhāsi.
segments.en: As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the heaven of the gods of the Thirty-Three and landed on Mount Vediyaka north of Ambasaṇḍā.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vediyako pabbato atiriva obhāsajāto hoti ambasaṇḍā ca brāhmaṇagāmo yathā taṃ devānaṃ devānubhāvena.
segments.en: Now at that time a dazzling light appeared over Mount Vediyaka and Ambasaṇḍā, as happens through the glory of the gods.
People in the villages round about, terrified, shocked, and awestruck, said,

segments.pli: “ādittassu nāmajja vediyako pabbato jhāyatisu nāmajja vediyako pabbato jalatisu. Nāmajja vediyako pabbato.
segments.en: “Mount Vediyaka must be on fire today, blazing and burning!

segments.pli: Kiṃsu nāmajja vediyako pabbato atiriva obhāsajāto ambasaṇḍā ca brāhmaṇagāmo”ti;
segments.en: Oh why has such a dazzling light appeared over Mount Vediyaka and Ambasaṇḍā?”

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṃ gandhabbadevaputtaṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Sakka addressed the fairy Pañcasikha,

segments.pli: “durupasaṅkamā kho, tāta pañcasikha, tathāgatā mādisena, jhāyī jhānaratā, tadantaraṃ paṭisallīnā.
segments.en: “My dear Pañcasikha, it’s hard for one like me to get near the Realized Ones while they are on retreat practicing absorption, enjoying absorption.

segments.pli: Yadi pana tvaṃ, tāta pañcasikha, bhagavantaṃ paṭhamaṃ pasādeyyāsi, tayā, tāta, paṭhamaṃ pasāditaṃ pacchā mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
segments.en: But if you were to charm the Buddha first, then I could go to see him.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ ādāya yena indasālaguhā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā:
segments.en: “Yes, lord,” replied the fairy Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went to the Indasāla cave. When he had drawn near, he stood to one side, thinking,

segments.pli: “ettāvatā me bhagavā neva atidūre bhavissati nāccāsanne, saddañca me sossatī”ti—
segments.en: “This is neither too far nor too near; and he’ll hear my voice.”
1. Pañcasikha’s Song

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ assāvesi, imā ca gāthā abhāsi buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṃghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā:
segments.en: Standing to one side, Pañcasikha played his arched harp, and sang these verses on the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the perfected ones, and sensual love.
“My lady Suriyavaccasā, oh my Sunshine—
I pay homage to your father Timbaru,
through whom was born a lady so fine,
to fill me with a joy I never knew.
As sweet as a breeze to one who’s sweating,
or when thirsty, a sweet and cooling drink,
so dear is your shining beauty to me,
just like the teaching is to all the saints!
Like a cure when you’re struck by fever dire,
or food to ease the hunger pain,
come on, darling, please put out my fire,
quench me like water on a flame.
As elephants burning in the heat of summer,
sink down in a lotus pond to rest,
so cool, full of petals and of pollen—
that’s how I would plunge into your breast.
Like elephants bursting bonds in rutting season,
beating off the pricks of lance and pikes—
I just don’t understand what is the reason
I’m so crazy for your shapely thighs!
For you, my heart is full of passion,
I’m in an altered state of mind.
There is no going back, I’m just not able,
I’m like a fish that’s hooked up on the line.
Come on, my darling, hold me, fair of thighs!
Embrace me, with your so bashful eyes!
Take me in your arms, my lovely lady,
that’s all I’d ever want or could desire.
Ah, then my desire was such a small thing,
my sweet, with your curling wavy hair;
now, like to arahants an offering,
it’s grown so very much from there.
Whatever the merit I have forged
by giving to such perfected beings—
may that, my altogether gorgeous,
ripen in togetherness with you.
Whatever the merit I have forged
in this wide open land,
may that, my altogether gorgeous,
ripen in togetherness with you.
Absorbed, the Sakyan meditates,
unified, alert, and mindful,
the sage aims right at the deathless state—
like me, oh my Sunshine, aiming for you!
And just like the sage would be rejoicing,
were he to awaken to the truth,
so I’d be rejoicing, lady,
were I to end up as one with you.
If Sakka were to grant me just one wish,
as Lord of the holy Thirty-Three,
my darling, you’re the only one I’d wish for,
so strong is the love I hold for you.
Like a freshly blossoming sal tree
is your father, my lady so wise.
I pay homage to him, bowing down humbly,
to he whose daughter is of such a kind.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā pañcasikhaṃ gandhabbadevaputtaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When Pañcasikha had spoken, the Buddha said to him,

segments.pli: “saṃsandati kho te, pañcasikha, tantissaro gītassarena, gītassaro ca tantissarena;
segments.en: “Pañcasikha, the sound of the strings and the sound of your voice blend well together,

segments.pli: na ca pana te, pañcasikha, tantissaro gītassaraṃ ativattati, gītassaro ca tantissaraṃ.
segments.en: so that neither overpowers the other.

segments.pli: Kadā saṃyūḷhā pana te, pañcasikha, imā gāthā buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṃghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā”ti?
segments.en: But when did you compose these verses on the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the perfected ones, and sensual love?”

segments.pli: “Ekamidaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
segments.en: “This one time, sir, when you were first awakened, you were staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

segments.pli: Tena kho panāhaṃ, bhante, samayena bhaddā nāma sūriyavacchasā timbaruno gandhabbarañño dhītā, tamabhikaṅkhāmi.
segments.en: And at that time I was in love with the lady named Bhaddā Suriyavaccasā, the daughter of the fairy king Timbaru.

segments.pli: Sā kho pana, bhante, bhaginī parakāminī hoti;
segments.en: But the sister desired another—

segments.pli: sikhaṇḍī nāma mātalissa saṅgāhakassa putto, tamabhikaṅkhati.
segments.en: it was Mātali the charioteer’s son named Sikhaḍḍī who she loved.

segments.pli: Yato kho ahaṃ, bhante, taṃ bhaginiṃ nālatthaṃ kenaci pariyāyena.
segments.en: Since I couldn’t win that sister by any means,

segments.pli: Athāhaṃ beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ ādāya yena timbaruno gandhabbarañño nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ assāvesiṃ, imā ca gāthā abhāsiṃ buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṃghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā—
segments.en: I took my arched harp to Timbaru’s home, where I played those verses.

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, bhaddā sūriyavacchasā maṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When I finished, Suriyavacchasā said to me,

segments.pli: ‘na kho me, mārisa, so bhagavā sammukhā diṭṭho, api ca sutoyeva me so bhagavā devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ upanaccantiyā.
segments.en: ‘Dear sir, I have not personally seen the Buddha. But I did hear about him when I went to dance for the gods of the Thirty-Three in the Hall of Justice.

segments.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, mārisa, taṃ bhagavantaṃ kittesi, hotu no ajja samāgamo’ti.
segments.en: Since you extol the Buddha, let us meet up today.’

segments.pli: Soyeva no, bhante, tassā bhaginiyā saddhiṃ samāgamo ahosi.
segments.en: And that’s when I met up with that sister.
But we have not met since.”
2. The Approach of Sakka
Then Sakka, lord of gods, thought,

segments.pli: “paṭisammodati pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto bhagavatā, bhagavā ca pañcasikhenā”ti.
segments.en: “Pañcasikha is exchanging pleasantries with the Buddha.”

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṃ gandhabbadevaputtaṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: So he addressed Pañcasikha,
“My dear Pañcasikha, please bow to the Buddha for me, saying:

segments.pli: ‘sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’”ti.
segments.en: ‘Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.’”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādeti:
segments.en: “Yes, lord,” replied Pañcasikha. He bowed to the Buddha and said,

segments.pli: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ sukhī hotu, pañcasikha, sakko devānamindo sāmacco saparijano;
segments.en: “So may Sakka with his ministers and retinue be happy, Pañcasikha,” said the Buddha,

segments.pli: sukhakāmā hi devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā”ti.
segments.en: “for all want to be happy—whether gods, humans, demons, dragons, fairies, or any of the other diverse creatures there may be.”

segments.pli: Evañca pana tathāgatā evarūpe mahesakkhe yakkhe abhivadanti.
segments.en: For that is how the Realized Ones salute such illustrious spirits.

segments.pli: Abhivadito sakko devānamindo bhagavato indasālaguhaṃ pavisitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
segments.en: And being saluted by the Buddha, Sakka entered the Indasāla cave, bowed to the Buddha, and stood to one side.

segments.pli: Devāpi tāvatiṃsā indasālaguhaṃ pavisitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
segments.en: And the gods of the Thirty-Three did likewise,

segments.pli: Pañcasikhopi gandhabbadevaputto indasālaguhaṃ pavisitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
segments.en: as did Pañcasikha.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena indasālaguhā visamā santī samā samapādi, sambādhā santī urundā samapādi, andhakāro guhāyaṃ antaradhāyi, āloko udapādi yathā taṃ devānaṃ devānubhāvena.
segments.en: And at that time the uneven places were evened out, the cramped places were opened up, the darkness vanished and light appeared, as happens through the glory of the gods.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the Buddha said to Sakka,

segments.pli: “acchariyamidaṃ āyasmato kosiyassa, abbhutamidaṃ āyasmato kosiyassa tāva bahukiccassa bahukaraṇīyassa yadidaṃ idhāgamanan”ti.
segments.en: “It’s incredible and amazing that you, the venerable Kosiya, who has so many duties and so much to do, should come here.”

segments.pli: “Cirapaṭikāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo; api ca devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ kehici kehici kiccakaraṇīyehi byāvaṭo; evāhaṃ nāsakkhiṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
segments.en: “For a long time I’ve wanted to go and see the Buddha, but I wasn’t able, being prevented by my many duties and responsibilities for the gods of the Thirty-Three.

segments.pli: Ekamidaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati salaḷāgārake.
segments.en: This one time, sir, the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the frankincense-tree hut.

segments.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhante, sāvatthiṃ agamāsiṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
segments.en: Then I went to Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana, bhante, samayena bhagavā aññatarena samādhinā nisinno hoti, bhūjati ca nāma vessavaṇassa mahārājassa paricārikā bhagavantaṃ paccupaṭṭhitā hoti, pañjalikā namassamānā tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: But at that time the Buddha was sitting immersed in some kind of meditation. And a divine maiden of Great King Vessavaṇa named Bhūjati was attending on the Buddha, standing there paying homage to him with joined palms.
So I said to her,
‘Sister, please bow to the Buddha for me, saying:

segments.pli: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”’ti.
segments.en: “Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.”’

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sā bhūjati maṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When I said this, she said to me,
‘It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
as he’s in retreat.’

segments.pli: ‘Tena hi, bhagini, yadā bhagavā tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito hoti, atha mama vacanena bhagavantaṃ abhivādehi:
segments.en: ‘Well then, sister, please convey my message when the Buddha emerges from that immersion.’

segments.pli: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”’ti.
Kacci me sā, bhante, bhaginī bhagavantaṃ abhivādesi?
segments.en: I hope that sister bowed to you?
Do you remember what she said?”

segments.pli: “Abhivādesi maṃ sā, devānaminda, bhaginī, sarāmahaṃ tassā bhaginiyā vacanaṃ.
segments.en: “She did bow, lord of gods, and I remember what she said.

segments.pli: Api cāhaṃ āyasmato nemisaddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito”ti.
segments.en: I also remember that it was the sound of your chariot wheels that pulled me out of that immersion.”

segments.pli: “Ye te, bhante, devā amhehi paṭhamataraṃ tāvatiṃsakāyaṃ upapannā, tesaṃ me sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
segments.en: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the gods who were reborn in the host of the Thirty-Three before me:

segments.pli: ‘yadā tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā, dibbā kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
segments.en: ‘When a Realized One arises in the world, perfected and fully awakened, the heavenly hosts swell, while the demon hosts dwindle.’

segments.pli: Taṃ me idaṃ, bhante, sakkhidiṭṭhaṃ yato tathāgato loke uppanno arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dibbā kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyāti.
segments.en: And I have seen this with my own eyes.
2.1. The Story of Gopikā

segments.pli: Idheva, bhante, kapilavatthusmiṃ gopikā nāma sakyadhītā ahosi buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṃghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārinī.
segments.en: Right here in Kapilavatthu there was a Sakyan lady named Gopikā who had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled her ethics.

segments.pli: Sā itthittaṃ virājetvā purisattaṃ bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā.
segments.en: Losing her attachment to femininity, she developed masculinity. When her body broke up, after death, she was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

segments.pli: Devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ amhākaṃ puttattaṃ ajjhupagatā.
segments.en: In the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three she became one of my sons.
There they knew him as
the god Gopaka.

segments.pli: Aññepi, bhante, tayo bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ caritvā hīnaṃ gandhabbakāyaṃ upapannā.
segments.en: Meanwhile three others, mendicants who had led the spiritual life under the Buddha, were reborn in the inferior fairy realm.

segments.pli: Te pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārayamānā amhākaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchanti amhākaṃ pāricariyaṃ.
segments.en: There they amused themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, and became my servants and attendants.

segments.pli: Te amhākaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgate amhākaṃ pāricariyaṃ gopako devaputto paṭicodesi:
segments.en: At that, Gopaka scolded them,

segments.pli: ‘kutomukhā nāma tumhe, mārisā, tassa bhagavato dhammaṃ assuttha—
segments.en: ‘Where on earth were you at, good sirs, when you heard the Buddha’s teaching!

segments.pli: ahañhi nāma itthikā samānā buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṃghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārinī itthittaṃ virājetvā purisattaṃ bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā, devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ sakkassa devānamindassa puttattaṃ ajjhupagatā.
segments.en: For while I was still a woman I had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled my ethics. I lost my attachment to femininity and developed masculinity. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. In the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three I became one of Sakka’s sons.
Here they know me as
the god Gopaka.

segments.pli: Tumhe pana, mārisā, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ caritvā hīnaṃ gandhabbakāyaṃ upapannā.
segments.en: But you, having led the spiritual life under the Buddha, were reborn in the inferior fairy realm.’

segments.pli: Duddiṭṭharūpaṃ vata bho addasāma, ye mayaṃ addasāma sahadhammike hīnaṃ gandhabbakāyaṃ upapanne’ti.
Tesaṃ, bhante, gopakena devaputtena paṭicoditānaṃ dve devā diṭṭheva dhamme satiṃ paṭilabhiṃsu kāyaṃ brahmapurohitaṃ, eko pana devo kāme ajjhāvasi.
segments.en: When scolded by Gopaka, two of those gods in that very life gained mindfulness leading to the host of Brahmā’s Ministers. But one god remained attached to sensuality.
‘I was a laywoman disciple of the seer,
and my name was Gopikā.
I was devoted to the Buddha and the teaching,
and I faithfully served the Saṅgha.
Because of the excellence of the Buddha’s teaching,
I’m now a mighty, splendid son of Sakka,
reborn among the Three and Thirty.
And here they know me as Gopaka.
Then I saw some mendicants who I’d seen before,
dwelling in the host of fairies.
When I used to be a human,
they were disciples of Gotama.
I served them with food and drink,
and clasped their feet in my own home.
Where on earth were they at
when they learned the Buddha’s teachings?
For each must know for themselves the teaching
so well-taught, realized by the seer.
I was one who followed you,
having heard the fine words of the noble ones.
I’m now a mighty, splendid son of Sakka,
reborn among the Three and Thirty.
But you followed the best of men,
and led the supreme spiritual life,
but still you’re born in this lesser realm,
a rebirth not befitting.
It’s a sorry sight I see, good sirs,
fellow Buddhists in a lesser realm.
Reborn in the host of fairies,
you only wait upon the gods.
Meanwhile, I dwelt in a house—
but see my distinction now!
Having been a woman now I’m a male god,
blessed with heavenly sensual pleasures.’
Scolded by that disciple of Gotama,
when they understood Gopaka, they were struck with urgency.
‘Let’s strive, let’s try hard—
we won’t serve others any more!’
Two of them aroused energy,
recalling the Buddha’s instructions.
Right away they became dispassionate,
seeing the drawbacks in sensual pleasures.
The fetters and bonds of sensual pleasures—
the ties of the Wicked One so hard to break—
they burst them like a bull elephant his ropes,
and passed right over the Thirty-Three.
The gods with Inda and Pajāpati
were all gathered in the Hall of Justice.
As they sat there, they passed over them,
the heroes desireless, practicing purity.
Seeing them, Vāsava was struck with a sense of urgency;
the master of gods in the midst of the group said,
‘These were born in the lesser fairy realm,
but now they pass us by!’
Heeding the speech of one so moved,
Gopaka addressed Vāsava,
‘There is a Buddha, a lord of men, in the world.
Known as the Sakyan Sage, he’s mastered the senses.
Those sons of his were bereft of mindfulness;
but when scolded by me they gained it back.
Of the three, there is one who remains
dwelling in the host of fairies.
But two, recollecting the path to awakening,
serene, spurn even the gods.’
The teaching’s explained in such a way
that not a single disciple doubts it.
We venerate the Buddha, the victor, lord of men,
who has crossed the flood and cut off doubt.
They attained to distinction fitting
the extent to which they understood the teaching here.
Two of them mastered the distinction of
the host of Brahmā’s Ministers.
We have come here, dear sir,
to realize this same teaching.
If the Buddha would give me a chance,
I would ask a question, dear sir.”
Then the Buddha thought,

segments.pli: “dīgharattaṃ visuddho kho ayaṃ yakkho, yaṃ kiñci maṃ pañhaṃ pucchissati, sabbaṃ taṃ atthasañhitaṃyeva pucchissati, no anatthasañhitaṃ.
segments.en: “For a long time now this spirit has led a pure life. Any question he asks me will be beneficial, not useless.

segments.pli: Yañcassāhaṃ puṭṭho byākarissāmi, taṃ khippameva ājānissatī”ti.
segments.en: And he will quickly understand any answer I give to his question.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: So the Buddha addressed Sakka in verse:
“Ask me your question, Vāsava,

I’ll solve each and every
problem you have.”

segments.pli: Tasmā na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti.
segments.en: That’s why not all ascetics and brahmins have the same doctrine, ethics, desires, and attachments.”

segments.pli: “Sabbeva nu kho, mārisa, samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti?
segments.en: “Dear sir, have all ascetics and brahmins reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal?”

segments.pli: “Na kho, devānaminda, sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti.
segments.en: “No, lord of gods, they have not.”

segments.pli: “Kasmā pana, mārisa, na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti?
segments.en: “Why not?”

segments.pli: “Ye kho, devānaminda, bhikkhū taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttā te accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā.
segments.en: “Those mendicants who are freed through the ending of craving have reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal.

segments.pli: Tasmā na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti.
segments.en: That’s why not all ascetics and brahmins have reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal.”

segments.pli: Itthaṃ bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākāsi.
segments.en: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.

segments.pli: Attamano sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandi anumodi:
segments.en: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,
“That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

segments.pli: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṃ sutvā”ti.
segments.en: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”

segments.pli: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: And then Sakka asked another question:

segments.pli: “Ejā, bhante, rogo, ejā gaṇḍo, ejā sallaṃ, ejā imaṃ purisaṃ parikaḍḍhati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
segments.en: “Passion, sir, is a disease, an abscess, a dart. Passion drags a person to be reborn in life after life.
That’s why a person finds themselves in states high and low.

segments.pli: Yesāhaṃ, bhante, pañhānaṃ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu okāsakammampi nālatthaṃ, te me bhagavatā byākatā.
segments.en: Elsewhere, among other ascetics and brahmins, I wasn’t even given a chance to ask these questions that the Buddha has answered.

segments.pli: Dīgharattānusayitañca pana me vicikicchākathaṃkathāsallaṃ, tañca bhagavatā abbuḷhan”ti.
segments.en: The dart of doubt and uncertainty has lain within me for a long time, but the Buddha has plucked it out.”

segments.pli: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṃ, devānaminda, ime pañhe aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti?
segments.en: “Lord of gods, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”

segments.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, bhante, ime pañhe aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti.
segments.en: “I do, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana te, devānaminda, byākaṃsu? Sace te agaru bhāsassū”ti.
segments.en: “If you wouldn’t mind, lord of gods, tell me how they answered.”

segments.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, garu yatthassa bhagavā nisinno bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
segments.en: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”
“Well, speak then, lord of gods.”

segments.pli: “Yesvāhaṃ, bhante, maññāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇā āraññikā pantasenāsanāti, tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe pucchāmi, te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaṃyeva paṭipucchanti:
segments.en: “Sir, I approached those who I imagined were ascetics and brahmins living in the wilderness, in remote lodgings. But they could not answer, and they even questioned me in return:
‘What is the venerable’s name?’
So I answered them:
‘Dear sir, I am Sakka, lord of gods.’
So they asked me another question:

segments.pli: ‘kiṃ panāyasmā, devānaminda, kammaṃ katvā imaṃ ṭhānaṃ patto’ti?
segments.en: ‘But lord of gods, what deed brought you to this position?’
So I taught them the Dhamma as I had learned and memorized it.
And they were pleased with just that much:

segments.pli: ‘sakko ca no devānamindo diṭṭho, yañca no apucchimhā, tañca no byākāsī’ti.
segments.en: ‘We have seen Sakka, lord of gods! And he answered our questions!’

segments.pli: Te aññadatthu mamaṃyeva sāvakā sampajjanti, na cāhaṃ tesaṃ.
segments.en: Invariably, they become my disciples, I don’t become theirs.

segments.pli: Ahaṃ kho pana, bhante, bhagavato sāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
segments.en: But sir, I am the Buddha’s disciple, a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
2.5. On Feeling Happy

segments.pli: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṃ, devānaminda, ito pubbe evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti?
segments.en: “Lord of gods, do you recall ever feeling such joy and happiness before?”

segments.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, bhante, ito pubbe evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti.
segments.en: “I do, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, devānaminda, abhijānāsi ito pubbe evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti?
segments.en: “But how?”
“Once upon a time, sir, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.

segments.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhante, saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājayiṃsu.
segments.en: In that battle the gods won and the demons lost.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmassa etadahosi:
segments.en: It occurred to me as victor,

segments.pli: ‘yā ceva dāni dibbā ojā yā ca asurā ojā, ubhayametaṃ devā paribhuñjissantī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Now the gods shall enjoy both the nectar of the gods and the nectar of the demons.’

segments.pli: So kho pana me, bhante, vedapaṭilābho somanassapaṭilābho sadaṇḍāvacaro sasatthāvacaro na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
segments.en: But sir, that joy and happiness is in the sphere of the rod and the sword. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

segments.pli: Yo kho pana me ayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā vedapaṭilābho somanassapaṭilābho, so adaṇḍāvacaro asatthāvacaro ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattatī”ti.
segments.en: But the joy and happiness I feel listening to the Buddha’s teaching is not in the sphere of the rod and the sword. It does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”

segments.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, devānaminda, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedesī”ti?
segments.en: “But lord of gods, what reason do you see for speaking of such joy and happiness?”

segments.pli: “Cha kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavase sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: “I see six reasons to speak of such joy and happiness, sir.
While staying right here,
remaining in the godly form,
I have gained an extended life:
know this, dear sir.

segments.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, paṭhamaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: This is the first reason.
When I fall from the heavenly host,
leaving behind the non-human life,
I shall consciously go to a new womb,
wherever my mind delights.

segments.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, dutiyaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: This is the second reason.
Living happily under the guidance
of the one of unclouded wisdom,
I shall practice according to method,
aware and mindful.

segments.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, tatiyaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: This is the third reason.
And if awakening should arise
as I practice according to the method,
I shall live as one who understands,
and my end shall come right there.

segments.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, catutthaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: This is the fourth reason.
When I fall from the human realm,
leaving behind the human life,
I shall become a god again,
in the supreme heaven realm.

segments.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, pañcamaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: This is the fifth reason.
They are the finest of gods,
the glorious Akaniṭṭhas.
So long as my final life goes on,
there my home will be.

segments.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, chaṭṭhaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: This is the sixth reason.

segments.pli: Ime kho ahaṃ, bhante, cha atthavase sampassamāno evarūpaṃ vedapaṭilābhaṃ somanassapaṭilābhaṃ pavedemi.
segments.en: Seeing these six reasons I speak of such joy and happiness.
My wishes unfulfilled,
doubting and undecided,
I wandered for such a long time,
in search of the Realized One.
I imagined that ascetics
living in seclusion
must surely be awakened,
so I went to sit near them.
‘How is there success?
How is there failure?’
But they couldn’t answer such questions
about the path and practice.
And when they found out that I
was Sakka, come from the gods,
they questioned me instead about
the deed that brought me to this state.
I taught them the Dhamma
as I had learned it among men.
They were delighted with that, saying:
‘We’ve seen Vāsava!’
Now since I’ve seen the Buddha,
who helps us overcome doubt,
today, free of fear,
I pay homage to the awakened one.
Destroyer of the dart of craving,
the Buddha is unrivaled.
I bow to the great hero,
the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun.
Just as Brahmā is worshipped
by the gods, dear sir,
today we shall worship you—
come, let us bow to you!
You alone are the Awakened!
You are the Teacher supreme!
In the world with its gods,
there is no-one like you.”

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṃ gandhabbaputtaṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Sakka addressed the fairy Pañcasikha,

segments.pli: “bahūpakāro kho mesi tvaṃ, tāta pañcasikha, yaṃ tvaṃ bhagavantaṃ paṭhamaṃ pasādesi.
segments.en: “Dear Pañcasikha, you were very helpful to me, since you first charmed the Buddha,

segments.pli: Tayā, tāta, paṭhamaṃ pasāditaṃ pacchā mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamimhā arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ.
segments.en: after which I went to see him.

segments.pli: Pettike vā ṭhāne ṭhapayissāmi, gandhabbarājā bhavissasi, bhaddañca te sūriyavacchasaṃ dammi, sā hi te abhipatthitā”ti.
segments.en: I shall appoint you to your father’s position—you shall be king of the fairies. And I give you Bhaddā Suriyavaccasā, who you love so much.”

segments.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pāṇinā pathaviṃ parāmasitvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then Sakka, touching the ground with his hand, was inspired to exclaim three times:
“Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”

segments.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne sakkassa devānamindassa virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
segments.en: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in Sakka, lord of gods:
“Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
And also for another 80,000 deities.

segments.pli: iti ye sakkena devānamindena ajjhiṭṭhapañhā puṭṭhā, te bhagavatā byākatā.
segments.en: Such were the questions Sakka was invited to ask, and which were answered by the Buddha.
And that’s why the name of this discussion is “Sakka’s Questions”.
